column1: '''Narchost''' was the western<ref name=UI/> of the two [[Towers of the Teeth]]
column2: <ref>{{TT|IV3}}</ref> that stood on two hills either side of the [[Black Gate]] of the Morannon
column3: guarding the northwestern entrance into [[Mordor]].  Narchost and its companion [[Carchost]] were originally built by the [[Gondorians]]
column4: as a guard upon Mordor after [[Sauron]]'s first defeat.  As Gondor's strength waned
column5: Narchost was abandoned and left to decay
column6: until Sauron returned to his ancient land.  His forces took over both the old guard-towers and repaired them
column7: so that at the time of the [[War of the Ring]]
column8: they formed part of Sauron's own defences.<ref name="Towers">{{RK|VI1}}</ref>

column1: In his [[Unfinished index]] for ''The Lord of the Rings''
column2: Tolkien translated the [[Sindarin]] name ''Narchost'' as "bitter-biting fort".<ref name=UI>{{HM|UI}}
column3: p. 601</ref> Its initial element ''narch'' "bitter-biting" is not otherwise attested
column4: but a similar ([[Noldorin]]) verb ''[[narcha-]]'' "to rend" appears in the ''Etymologies'' as a derivative of the root [[NÁRAK]].<ref>{{LR|Etymologies}}
